factoid: Rostóv did not know how he ran to his place and mounted.
Rostóv did not remember how he ran to his place and mounted.
Rostóv’s regret at not having been in action had gone.
Rostóv’s dejected mood among people he was weary of had gone.
Rostóv’s thoughts of himself had vanished.
Rostóv was filled with happiness at his nearness to the Emperor.
Rostóv felt that his nearness to the Emperor made up for the day he had lost.
Rostóv was happy as a lover when the longed-for moment of meeting arrived.
Rostóv was ecstatically conscious of his approach.
Rostóv felt the sound of the hoofs of the approaching cavalcade.
As Rostóv drew near, everything grew brighter.
As Rostóv drew near, everything grew more joyful.
As Rostóv drew near, everything grew more significant.
As Rostóv drew near, everything grew more festive.
The sun shed beams of mild and majestic light around Rostóv.
Rostóv felt himself enveloped in those beams.
Rostóv heard his voice, that kindly, calm, and majestic voice that was yet so simple.
There was a deathly stillness amid which the Emperor’s voice was heard.
Rostóv inquired, "The Pávlograd hussars?"
A voice replied, "The reserves, sire!"
The Emperor drew level with Rostóv and halted.
Alexander’s face was even more beautiful than it had been three days before at the review.
Alexander’s face shone with such gaiety and youth that it suggested the liveliness of a fourteen-year-old boy.
Alexander’s face was the face of the majestic Emperor.
The Emperor’s eyes met Rostóv’s.
The Emperor’s eyes rested on Rostóv’s for not more than two seconds.
The Emperor’s light-blue eyes gazed into Rostóv’s face for about two seconds.
A gentle, mild light poured from the Emperor’s eyes.
The Emperor raised his eyebrows.
The Emperor touched his horse with his left foot.
The Emperor galloped on.
The younger Emperor left the third column at twelve o’clock.
The younger Emperor galloped toward the vanguard.
Several adjutants met the Emperor with news of the successful result of the action.
The battle consisted in the capture of a French squadron.
The battle was represented as a brilliant victory over the French.
The Emperor and the whole army believed that the French had been defeated.
The Emperor and the whole army believed that the French were retreating against their will.
The Pávlograd division was ordered to advance a few minutes after the Emperor had passed.
In Wischau, a petty German town, Rostóv saw the Emperor again.
In the marketplace lay several killed and wounded soldiers.
There had not been time to move the killed and wounded soldiers.
The Emperor was riding a bobtailed chestnut mare.
The mare was different from the one the Emperor rode at the review.
The Emperor bent to one side.
The Emperor held a gold lorgnette to his eyes.
The Emperor looked at a soldier who lay prone with blood on his uncovered head.
The wounded soldier was so dirty, coarse, and revolting that his proximity to the Emperor shocked Rostóv.
The Emperor’s shoulders shuddered as if a cold shiver had run down them.
The Emperor’s left foot convulsively tapped the horse’s side with the spur.
The horse looked round unconcerned and did not stir.
An adjutant lifted the wounded soldier under the arms to place him on a stretcher.
The soldier groaned.
The Emperor said, "Gently, gently! Can’t you do it more gently?"
The Emperor apparently suffered more than the dying soldier.
The Emperor rode away.
Rostóv saw tears filling the Emperor’s eyes.
The Emperor said to Czartorýski, "What a terrible thing war is: what a terrible thing! Quelle terrible chose que la guerre!"
